definitions.definition: to leave somebody, especially somebody you are responsible for, with no intention of returning

examples.text: The baby had been abandoned by its mother.
People often simply abandon their pets when they go abroad.
‘We have been **abandoned to our fate**,’ said one resident.
The study showed a deep fear among the elderly of being abandoned to the care of strangers.

definitions.definition: to leave a thing or place, especially because it is impossible or dangerous to stay

examples.text: Snow forced many drivers to abandon their vehicles.
He gave the order to **abandon ship** *(= to leave the ship because it was sinking)*.
They had to abandon their lands to the invading forces.
Much of the land has now been abandoned in favour of more fertile areas to the south.
The town had been hastily abandoned.

definitions.definition: to stop doing something, especially before it is finished; to stop having something

examples.text: They abandoned the match because of rain.
The **plans **for reform were quietly **abandoned**.
She abandoned hope of any reconciliation.
We had to abandon any further attempt at negotiation.
She abandoned her teaching career in favour of sport.
The government does not propose to abandon the project altogether.
Traditional policies were simply abandoned.
They were forced to abandon the game because of rain.
Work on the new building was finally abandoned.
He abandoned the army for politics.

definitions.definition: to stop supporting or helping somebody; to stop believing in something

examples.text: The country abandoned its political leaders after the war.
Critics accused him of abandoning his principles.
This principle has now been effectively abandoned.

definitions.definition: to feel an emotion so strongly that you can feel nothing else

examples.text: He abandoned himself to despair.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French abandoner, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + bandon ‘control’ (related to ban). The original sense was ‘bring under control’, later ‘give in to the control of, surrender to’ (sense (5)).
